titlestmt.titleproper: Central Texas glass plate negative collection 100.2002
titlestmt.author: Original inventory by Roberto Gutierrez Jr., ArchivesSpace finding aid by Nicole Critchley

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-08-20 16:15:30 -0500.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.head: Collection Summary
did.unittitle: Central Texas glass plate negative collection
did.physloc: Materials may be stored off-site. Advance notice may be required for use.
did.abstract: This collection consists of 46 glass plate negatives showing images of San Antonio and San Marcos, Texas, and the surrounding area, as well as portraits dating from around 1892-1911. Notable images include Battle of Flowers parade, Fort Sam Houston, the Hays County Courthouse, the First United Methodist Church, and the Belgar-Cahill Lime Kiln.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Images are completely digitized. Access to original glass plate negatives is restricted due to their fragile nature. Researchers are encouraged to use the digital images available at the online exhibit. Please contact the University Archives for more information at univarchives@txstate.edu.

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: The glass plate negatives in this collection are of the "dry" type, which was a significant innovation. Before their invention in 1871, photographers had to prepare the glass plates and apply emulsions, expose, and develop them while still "wet." To process, or develop, the images, photographers needed a place that was free from light, a "darkroom." Thus, wet plate photographers needed either to remain close to their darkrooms or recreate them in the field.

Dry plate emulsions did not have the same time limitations as wet plate. Their stability allowed for greater mobility and convenience. Photographers could wait to expose their plates and then store them back in the box until they could be developed. Nevertheless, glass plates remained fragile and surprisingly heavy.

While dry glass plates allowed the practice of photography to spread to a larger number of people, it was the invention of roll film (1887) and Kodak's Brownie box camera (1900) which made photography widely accessible to the general public. Roll film was stable, lightweight, and a roll could be mailed to Kodak for developing and printing.

The photographer for this collection was using dry plates, we know they carried these heavy and fragile plates to locations to expose them, then carried them back to the darkroom to process them. The photographer likely needed considerable chemical and technical knowlege, specialized darkroom materials and equipment, and a dedicated work space to develop their plates and print photographs.
The glass plates arrived in Cramer's Lightning Dry Plate negative boxes. Mr. Cramer was a national supplier of dry plates beginning 1883.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of 46 glass plate negatives, measuring 4x5 inches, found in G. Cramer Dry Plate Company boxes. The photographer is unknown. Identified images within the collection were taken in San Antonio, Texas and San Marcos, Texas. These include views of the Hays County Courthouse, the First United Methodist Church, and the Belgar-Cahill Lime Kiln in San Marcos, Texas. A street view of San Marcos, Texas is also present. Others depict scenes from the Battle of Flowers parade in San Antonio, Texas. A few images show soldiers in formation engaged in military drills at Fort Sam Houston with Lambermot home and St. Paul's Episcopal Church in the background. Others show armed men on outdoor excursions or posed beside horse drawn carriages. Unidentified images depict men, women, and children in various forms of outdoor recreation, viewing machinery, or intentionally posed for portraiture. There are also images of various types of machinery. Dates for some negatives have been estimated upon their subjects. All others probably date between 1892-1911.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Item name, date.] Central Texas glass plate negative collection, 100.2002. University Archives, Texas State University.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Material in this collection is in the public domain.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: These materials were found at Goodwill in San Marcos, Texas and then donated by Mike Hughes and Helen Van Wieren in August 22, 2016.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: See also: Battle of Flowers Parade photos, University of Texas at San Antonio. As well as the San Marcos Daily Record photographic negative collection (100.SMDR).

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Original inventory and exhibit created by Roberto Gutierrez Jr., a Graduate Student in the Public History Program at the Texas State University, in the spring of 2018. Additional image identification by Alison Tudor and Dan Utley in 2020. Finding aid for ArchivesSpace created by Nicole Critchley in 2021.

did.unittitle: Six men with campfire and cookery tools in foreground
did.physdesc: Six men all wearing hats with campfire and cooking tools in foreground. Five men appear to be white, and one appears to be black. Two of the men are standing. Three men have pistols in holsters at waist. One is smoking and crouched to the ground, another is holding a metal cup and kneeling, and anther is using a piece of cloth to hold a pan which is resting on a wooden branch. Trees in background.

did.unittitle: Three white men standing on rocks in unknown river with truss bridge in background
did.physdesc: One man standing with hands at waist on large rock in an unknown river. Two other men on another rock behind him. Bridge in the far background.

did.unittitle: White woman reading at Jacob's Well, Wimberley, Texas.
Man standing on tall smoke stack, unknown industrial building

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Probably San Marcos Electric, Light, & Power Company, San Marcos, Texas.

did.unittitle: Man standing on tall smoke stack, unknown industrial building

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Probably San Marcos Electric, Light, & Power Company, San Marcos, Texas.

did.unittitle: Hays County Courthouse in San Marcos, Texas
did.physdesc: The Hays County Courthouse (1882-1908)in San Marcos, Texas. Designed by F.E. Ruffini.

did.unittitle: San Antonio Street, south side of the Square, San Marcos, Texas
did.physdesc: San Antonio Street between Austin (now LBJ) and Guadalupe Streets, San Marcos, Texas. From left to right: T.A. Porter, Fish & Oysters, Lone Star Bakery, and H.A. Nitzsche.

did.unittitle: Soldiers marching on the field, Fort Sam Houston, San Antonio, Texas. Second building from the left is Lambermont House, also known as Terrell Castle
Battle of Flowers Parade, Commerce Street, San Antonio, Texas.
did.physdesc: Battle of Flowers Parade on Commerce Street between Navarro and Saint Mary's streets in San Antonio Texas. Can see part of the D&A Oppenheimer Bank awning and Alamo Music Store.

did.unittitle: Battle of Flowers Parade, Commerce Street, San Antonio, Texas.
did.physdesc: Battle of Flowers Parade on Commerce Street between Navarro and Saint Mary's streets in San Antonio Texas. Can see Alamo Music Store storefront.

did.unittitle: Battle of Flowers Parade, Commerce Street, San Antonio, Texas.
did.physdesc: Mounted units in the Battle of Flowers Parade on Commerce Street between Navarro and Saint Mary's streets in San Antonio Texas. Floral decorations covering the carriage, the large boutonni√®res worn by the mounted soldiers, and the lavishly decorated hats and umbrellas of the women on-board. Can see part of the D&A Oppenheimer Bank awning and Alamo Music Store.

did.unittitle: Commerce Street, San Antonio, Texas.
did.physdesc: Commerce Street between Navarro and Saint Mary's streets in San Antonio Texas. Can see Alamo Music Store storefront.

did.unittitle: Soldiers marching in formation on the field
Mounted units on field. Fort Sam Houston, San Antonio, Texas
did.physdesc: Clock tower that overlooks Fort Sam Houston's Quadrangle seen along right edge of image.

did.unittitle: Three people on top of Belgar-Cahill Lime Kiln in San Marcos, Texas
did.physdesc: Two women and one man on top of Lime Kiln.

did.unittitle: Ten people sitting on ground around a picnic
View of double bend in unknown waterway
Seven people including children by a tree
did.physdesc: Group portrait of seven people including children. Rocking chair and hedge in background.

did.unittitle: View of unknown machine room containing belt driven electric generators
Three people sitting on ground having a picnic, river in background
View of downtown San Marcos, Texas, taken from Chautauqua Hill
did.physdesc: View of downtown San Marcos, Texas, taken from Chautauqua Hill where Old Main on Texas State University stands today. Includes Hays County Courthouse and the First United Methodist Church.
